node.contents: My consumer doesn't work the way I expect it to. Below is an sscce of what happens in my real program.

node.contents:
• Expected:
    1. Print In finally!
    2. Print About to print stacktrace
    3. Print a NullPointerException stacktrace.
  • Actual:
    1. Print In finally!
    2. Hang, in sun.misc.Unsafe

astNode.text:
• Expected:
    1. Print In finally!
    2. Print About to print stacktrace
    3. Print a NullPointerException stacktrace.
  • Actual:
    1. Print In finally!
    2. Hang, in sun.misc.Unsafe

elements.contents: import java.lang.Thread.UncaughtExceptionHandler; import java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService; import java.util.concurrent.Executors; import java.util.concurrent.ThreadFactory; public class ThreadTest implements Runnable { public static void main(String... args) { ExecutorService service = Executors.newSingleThreadExecutor(new ThreadFactory() { @Override public Thread newThread(Runnable r) { Thread newThread = new Thread(r); newThread.setUncaughtExceptionHandler(new MyExceptionHandler()); return newThread; } }); service.submit(new ThreadTest()); } private static class MyExceptionHandler implements UncaughtExceptionHandler { @Override public void uncaughtException(Thread t, Throwable e) { System.out.println("About to print stacktrace"); e.printStackTrace(); } } @Override public void run() { Object foo = null; try { while(!Thread.interrupted()) { Thread.sleep(1000); System.out.println(foo.toString()); System.out.println("After npe!"); } } catch(InterruptedException e) { } finally { System.out.println("In finally!"); } } }

units.rawText: import java.lang.Thread.UncaughtExceptionHandler; import java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService; import java.util.concurrent.Executors; import java.util.concurrent.ThreadFactory; public class ThreadTest implements Runnable { public static void main(String... args) { ExecutorService service = Executors.newSingleThreadExecutor(new ThreadFactory() { @Override public Thread newThread(Runnable r) { Thread newThread = new Thread(r); newThread.setUncaughtExceptionHandler(new MyExceptionHandler()); return newThread; } }); service.submit(new ThreadTest()); } private static class MyExceptionHandler implements UncaughtExceptionHandler { @Override public void uncaughtException(Thread t, Throwable e) { System.out.println("About to print stacktrace"); e.printStackTrace(); } } @Override public void run() { Object foo = null; try { while(!Thread.interrupted()) { Thread.sleep(1000); System.out.println(foo.toString()); System.out.println("After npe!"); } } catch(InterruptedException e) { } finally { System.out.println("In finally!"); } } }

node.contents: It hangs because you've not shutdown your executor service @durron597.

astNode.text: It hangs because you've not shutdown your executor service @durron597.

node.contents: You probably should use a `Callable` that will throw the NPE once you call future.get().

astNode.text: You probably should use a `Callable` that will throw the NPE once you call future.get().

node.contents: @Gray - the OP doesn't need to use Callable to get that to work, just hang on to the returned Future.

astNode.text: @Gray - the OP doesn't need to use Callable to get that to work, just hang on to the returned Future.

node.contents: True @jtahlborn. I instinctively move to `Callable` if I want the throw because it forces the catch but you are right when it's a `RuntimeException`.

astNode.text: True @jtahlborn. I instinctively move to `Callable` if I want the throw because it forces the catch but you are right when it's a `RuntimeException`.

node.contents: Well it turns out that for my real application, the thing that makes the most sense is to add a `catch (Throwable t)` and handle it there. But this answer got me on the right track, thanks!

astNode.text: Well it turns out that for my real application, the thing that makes the most sense is to add a `catch (Throwable t)` and handle it there. But this answer got me on the right track, thanks!

node.contents: Also I briefly considered using [`Executors.callable(Runnable task)`](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/Executors.html#callable%28java.lang.Runnable%29) before going this route, you may want to edit that into your post as well

astNode.text: Also I briefly considered using [`Executors.callable(Runnable task)`](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/Executors.html#callable%28java.lang.Runnable%29) before going this route, you may want to edit that into your post as well

node.contents: Runnables run inside an Executor don't really throw exceptions which will hit the thread's uncaught exception handler. Instead, the Runnable is wrapped with code which catches Throwable. This is so that a Future can return the exception that was thrown from the task.

astNode.text: Runnables run inside an Executor don't really throw exceptions which will hit the thread's uncaught exception handler. Instead, the Runnable is wrapped with code which catches Throwable. This is so that a Future can return the exception that was thrown from the task.

node.contents: as @Gray noted in the comments below, your program is "hanging" because the thread pool thread is keeping the program from exiting. your runnable has completed and the thread pool thread is just waiting for a new task. if you shutdown the thread pool, your program will complete normally (or make the thread pool threads daemon).

astNode.text: as @Gray noted in the comments below, your program is "hanging" because the thread pool thread is keeping the program from exiting. your runnable has completed and the thread pool thread is just waiting for a new task. if you shutdown the thread pool, your program will complete normally (or make the thread pool threads daemon).
